Run Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA)

Source: R/psychometrics.R
run_cfa.Rd

Wrapper around lavaan::cfa() for confirmatory factor analysis. Provides sensible defaults for consumer research while allowing full customization via pass-through arguments.

Usage

run_cfa(model, data, estimator = "MLR", missing = "fiml", std.lv = TRUE, ...)

Arguments

model

Character string specifying the CFA model in lavaan syntax

data

Data frame containing observed variables

estimator

Character. Estimator to use (default "MLR" = robust ML)

missing

Character. Missing data handling (default "fiml" = full information ML)

std.lv

Logical. Standardize latent variables? (default TRUE)

...

Additional arguments passed to lavaan::cfa()

Value

lavaan fit object (class lavaan)

Details

**Recommended defaults:** - estimator = "MLR": Maximum likelihood with robust (Huber-White) SEs - missing = "fiml": Full information maximum likelihood for missing data - std.lv = TRUE: Standardize latent variables (makes loadings interpretable)

**Alternative estimators:** - "ML": Standard maximum likelihood (faster, but not robust) - "WLSMV": Weighted least squares (for categorical data) - "ULS": Unweighted least squares (no distributional assumptions)

**lavaan model syntax:** “` # Latent variable defined by items satisfaction =~ q1 + q2 + q3 loyalty =~ q4 + q5 + q6

# Covariances satisfaction ~~ loyalty “`

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Define CFA model
model <- "
  # Latent variables
  satisfaction =~ sat1 + sat2 + sat3
  loyalty =~ loy1 + loy2 + loy3

  # Covariance
  satisfaction ~~ loyalty
"

# Run CFA
fit <- run_cfa(model, data = customer_survey)

# Get fit indices
fit_indices <- tidy_cfa_fit(fit)
} # }
